deploy-guide/source/upgrade-issues.rst.message:
The sudo ceph osd require-osd-release <version> only needs to be set on one of the mon nodes (its a cluster wide setting that is applied via the mons).

Secondly, before the upgrade - users can/should confirm that the `require_osd_release` setting is configured to the current version of ceph:

sudo ceph osd dump | grep require_osd_release

If the output contains an earlier release name than the current release (i.e. mimic when the installed ceph is nautilus), the require_osd_release setting should be set to the current release *before* the upgrade.
We should confirm whether the OSDs actually needed restarting or not in the preventative case.

I don't think this is documented in the right place. The specific issue we encountered that caused this was that we had previously set `sudo ceph osd require-osd-release mimic` previously. The Ceph documentation around upgrading [0] indicates that to complete a Ceph upgrade, you should run `sudo ceph osd require-osd-release <current-release>` in order to complete the upgrade and have the OSDs leverage all the features available in that release.

As such, I think this belongs in the upgrade documentation and not as an upgrade issue in its current form.

[0] - https://docs.ceph.com/en/latest/releases/pacific/#upgrading-non-cephadm-clusters

Revisiting this a bit, the Ceph documentation for upgrading to Octopus says that it can upgrade from [Mimic,Nautilus] -> Octopus but you must first get to one of those levels. Which in the above case of Train to Ussuri, the version is mimic and the upgrade should work. This gets me thinking that there's a regression (intentional or bug) in the Octopus version.

Which makes retract my -1 on this being documented as an upgrade issue, as there's clearly a bug. However, I'm concerned that users will run into this as part of the upgrade and really I believe they can take preventative measures to avoid running into this. The effects of running into this bug is that your entire ceph cluster will be taken offline, which is naturally not good. This leads me to the thinking that the documentation for how to upgrade Ceph should be updated, especially while a bug fix and investigation is pending to avoid the issue. This does mean that once the charm is fixed, we would need to update the documentation again unless we take this into consideration as we write the docs.
I'm wondering if the examples within here are too specific to the nautilus to octopus upgrade and its not clear enough that this should be done after each upgrade and release.

again you might want to highlight the positives here - faster builds, less cpu/memory usage, etc...
You need a blank line here to get the bullet points to render properly.
Might be nice to add these to the references section below, but not a big deal.
I have to do an update to address a comment by Scott so I will fix this as well.

Unqualified use of 'repository' or 'repo' leaves a bit of room for ambiguity.  Do they mean a package repository? A code repository? Perhaps even a image repository?  I encourage you to be specific about what type of repository is being discussed, or being manipulated by the stx sub-command.

Actually. I have to think about how to approach this some. The repository is also not only restricted to packages, it will be used to host sources as well. So the name should remain the same as it is a repository, just as folks use "repository" as a short form for "git repository". At any rate I don't think we need to expand the name to "Package and Source Repository Manager", but I will provide some context in the text here to remove ambiguity and as I mentioned before we will do the same in the help text and documentation.

Are you envisioning sub commands to deal separately with different repository types?  Or will they be linked, advancing in lock step ?  

There might also be a need to distinguish input packages (to satisfy build requirements for a package) from output packages e.g. a package that needs itself to build itself.  Low level stuff like bash, gcc, glibc, rpm (deb).  We hit that a few times.  You might even notice under centos we build rpm twice.  First pass, use stock rpm to build patches rpm,  then used patched rpm to rebuild rpm, so that rpm-<ver>.rpm was itself packaged using an updated signing technique.

As my note indicates the repository management here is strictly for the handling of the Debian package and source repository. This will be covered in more detail in an upcoming spec covering Pulp, which is the tool which will be proposed to implement the repository management. Pulp has a concept of publications and distributions which can be exploited for a scenario as you describe above, so a 'pristine' distribution can host the unmodified upstream packages and sources, a 'stx' distribution would host the output of a build which is patched and signed and each developer can have one or more 'scratch' distributions to host output from their work in progress builds. Once this spec is approved I will be presenting further specs which will touch on this in further detail.

Agreed. Repository is an overloaded term. In this case Debian package repository as described by https://wiki.debian.org/DebianRepository/Format is intended. I will add 'package' here and ensure that help text and documentation also make this distinction.

grep for ' _, ' and ', _ ' found 33 occurrences in the octavia tree, only 3 in tempest though in the go server...  '__' ? :)

I was trying to base my comments on the existing code.

We don't use "_" as a throw away variable in Octavia. It is a bad practice and leads to errors.
"_" has multiple meanings in python, including being used for I18n. This causes linting failures as well as potential runtime issues.
The best practice is to use the index like Arkady did here.

Maybe that instead of using "_" as a throwaway variable (not a good practice) it was decided to have not used "listener_id" instead, but why not simply indexing what we actually need to call  functions, like: pool_id = self._listener_pool_create(const.HTTP, 80)[1]?
Personally I think a throw-away is cleaner, and it's done elsewhere.  I'm not sure what others think.

Isn't that the root cause of the issue? Why aren't these files present in the backup when it is taken on controller-1? If these files are missing on controller-1, what else is broken?

During initial bootstrap, these keys are generated under/etc/etcd which is not drbd synced, so it is not present on controller-1. Then at a later time a task copies them from /etc/etcd to /etc/kubernetes/pki.
The task is 'Copy ca, cert and key generated by etcd to kubeadm_pki_dir'.

The idea of the commit was to simply allow the files to be present in /etc/etcd at the time the copy task is reached.

Nothing seems to be broken since swacting to controller-1 doesn't have the /etc/etcd files and normal functioning of the system is still achieved (otherwise it would have been caught in a few months since the issue was introduced), and the files in /etc/etcd seem to be used only for bootstrap logic.
This is no longer correct.

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/boots.message: So if the key/certificate under /etc/etcd are only used at bootstrap and are not maintained, should we be using them at all? What if the certificate has expired? Would it be better to always use the keys from /etc/kubernetes/pki which I assume would be updated if we had to renew these certificates?
Correct, /etc/etcd not maintained. We should always use from /etc/kubernetes/pki.

so the default sharding conf returns the defaults as they should appear once they've been preocessed by the __init__ method of the sharder, not as they are defined in the acutal sharder config?

Because in the sharder conf these are percents not object count values, as I see they've modified in the init_sharding_conf.

I'm not saying it's wrong. I guess it's the fact that we're using CONF with value that doesn't actaully match the config values make it a little confusing.

Should we just get rid of the whole percentage and just use whole values in config. It might make it easier and less confusing? Though the advantage of percentages it they're usful to get the number of knobs down as everything was derived from the shard_container_threshold _but_ could be overridden, if we go with absolutes, when container_threshold grows you must also edit other options.

Yeah, it is kinda annoying to have defaults for things only if others happen to be defaults too. But I like to think the next patch is depricating the percentages, so this patch is a stepping stone. You've cleanup up the amount of config option translations that needs to happen, and simlified the code.

I included rows_per_shard, shrink_threshold and expansion_limit (precomputed default values) as a convenience so that in s-m-s-r we can refer to something for the defaults in the parser args help strings. Also, a bit of a nod to the next patch which makes the configurable options in their own right.

rows_per_shard_percent is added just for consistency with the other percent based options, instead of a hard coded divide-by-2.

It is a little odd in that these defaults are only default when other options are at their default values, but I couldn't think of a way round this other than very complex help strings in s-m-s-r.

If it too confusing to have them here I could just move them back to constant declarations in manage_shard_ranges?

I'll add more comment.
nice clean up.

see below - it was not intended to become a configurable option
this can be conf[conf_key] and becomes that in the next patch: all the keys have been given default vals before set_val is called
is rows_per_shard_percent a new config option?

No that was not the intention but it has accidentally become so. I'll add an exclusion to prevent it being set from conf file. It may be useful to be able to set it, but that is not the goal of this patch and there is already enough going on here for one patch.

Good catch!

In the spirit of DRY and single-source-of-truth, I attempted to fold this into DEFAULT_SHARDER_CONF as a kind of "schema definition" type thing.  I encountered two problems, but all related to this percent based options

1) dict literals don't preserve order, so our schema wouldn't be indexable by key
2) percent_of_threshold really wants to close over namespace.shard_container_threshold

... so it's hard to make the schema with all our requirements as a global

FWIW, I overcame the ordering and percent dependency issues by having an PercentOption class that held a reference to an Option class instance. Both classes provide a method to parse their option from the conf.

So instead of needing to parse the threshold value first and then pass that *value* to the percent value parser, the percent value PercentOption parser would parse the threshold value on demand using its reference to the threshold Option.
this is the only place we use rows_per_shard in the sharder

neutron/tests/unit/conf/policies/test_qo.message:
So, it looks like policies are created for individual projects by system-administrators?

A project-admin or project-member (using secure RBAC) shouldn't be allowed to create their own policies, right?
yes, it's configured like that but maybe we should change it to allow project admin to create QoS policy as well?

Ok - sounds good. Maybe we can investigate that in a separate change.

One of the biggest advantages to this effort is making room to push more functionality down to project users where appropriate, and offload things system-administrators have to do for end-users.
This question isn't really related to the testing effort directly, but what are the alias for?
yeah, we should deprecate old API
No, policy should be the same for both.

Ok - interesting, thanks for the context.

Is there an advantage to maintaining separate policies for those aliased APIs? If I deploy neutron and start changing the alias policies to be different from the non-aliased API, will things work as expected? Does it make sense to lock down the alias API and not the non-aliased API?

originally our API had endpoints like /v2.0/qos/policies/{policy_id}/bandwidth_limit_rules so it required always to pass policy id for rule.
But at some point we noticed that this isn't really needed so to improve user experience, we proposed aliases, see: https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/#quality-of-service-rules-alias-api
Interesting - would it be worth while considering a deprecated for removal strategy for these (at some point in the future)?

Similar question as above. This API was never really exposed to project users? Minimum bandwidth rules must be managed by system-administrators?

I ask because it looks like the rule itself contains a project_id, so I'm wondering if this is something that could be pushed down to project users eventually (assuming it can be done safely), offloading some of the work system-admins have to do on behalf of projects.
For now it's like that but that's good question. Maybe we should change it?

I'll leave that call to the neutron maintainers since they're obviously more familiar with the implications of that decision.

But, if the new personas help push more functionality down to project-users safely, then that seems like a good idea.

May be should create a bucket to work through all these types of APIs during the PTG?
